div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

MONDAY, DECEMBER 23, 1907.

div.head: International Comity
div.p: It is to be deplored that the French Press in Egypt should so often be the mouthpiece of malevolent chauvinism. On Friday last for example, a Cairo French paper iusisted that Germany bad seized npon the events in Morocco to bring about a European conflagration. On the following day it was alleged that the differences between the Shah and his people are being fostered and manipulated by Germany in order to set England and Russia by the ears. Really, such disingenuous endeavours to create international discord are onworthy of those who claim to represent a generous intellectual and civilizing nation. Attempts of this kind, every enlightend man knows, are doomed to failure ; but tbat does not lessen in our eyes the obviously evil intention with which such reports are disseminated. The green-eyed monster is making himself too ostentatiously apparent. This policy of pin-pricks is the outward and visible sign of irrepressible envy at the cordial relations establisbed recently between two great kindred nations which culminated in the dazzling success of the Kaiser's visit to England. That his desire for friendsbip is spontaneously genuine the follow. ing unstudied utterance leaves no room for doubt:

"There must be peace between these two countries and I think that the English people will find me the best friend they ever had. We cannot afford to quarrel. I bope I make it clear that my feeling towards England is one of affection "And the expression of this feeling has been re echoed througbout the length and breadth of the Fatherland. "His Majesty's stay in England," as has been well said, "bag clotbed Anglo-German relations with the warmth and sincerity of mutual goodwill, the influence of which should be long felt." The Englisb man's love of fair-play is proverbial ; and, especially in the light of wat has just happened he cannot view with equanimity the shabby attacks indulged in by the French Press in Egypt or elsewhere upon the German nation. In this month's "Empire Review" an article from the pen of a familiar figure in Cairo, – to wit, Mr. Dicey, - Accurately diagnoses the situation.

"The ordinary Englishman," be writes, "s the most good-natured in the world, and when be was ass red that France was willing to shake hands and let bygones be bygones be was perfectly willing to reciprocate the senti. ment. As soon, however, as he learnt that in French opinion the entente cordiale was only a prelude to an offensive and defensive alliance by which Germany was to be deprived of her supremacy as the greatest of Continental Powers the enthusiasm for the Anglo-Prench Agreement dwindled away."
Let our French contemporaries take these words seriously to heart. No truer reflection of unanimous British sentiment could possibly be furnished

div.head: Alhambra Theatre.
div.p: The Committee of Bankers will meet on Monday at the Credit Foncier offices to deliberate upon the Cairo Bourse question.

div.head: Suez Canal Company.

div.head: Cairo Circulating Library.
div.p: The Library will be closed on Wednesday and Thursday 25th and 26th inst.

div.head: Chezireh Palace.
div.p: The first small dance at the Ghezirel Palace Hotel will be held on Boxing Day. Dances will from that date be held every Thursday evening.

div.head: Italian Charity Society.
div.p: The grand "'veglione" of the Société Italienne de Bienfaisance will take place at the Alhambra Theatre, Alexandria, on the 1 th prox.

div.head: Alexandria and Ramieh Railway Co.
div.p: Boghos Pasha Nubar intends to resign his position as chairmain of the Board of Directors of the Alexandria and Ramleh Railway Company Limited.

div.head: British and Foreign Bible Society.
div.p: The British and Foreign Bible Society have opened a Depot in Sharia El Madabegh, Cairo (near the National Bank) where scriptures may be purchased in all languages

div.head: The Behera Co.
div.p: This company has just sold 250 feddans of land to various native proprietors at prices from L.E. 12 to L.E. 50 per feddan. These lands are not yet cultivated, but are provided with canals and drains.

div.head: The Fregoli Case.
div.p: The action bronght by Mr. Serafini against the celebrated impersonator, Fregoli, for breach of contract came before the Italian Consular Court at Alexandria this morning and was postponed until Friday next

div.head: The 'Heliopolis.'
div.p: The "Heliopolis" left Marseilles at noon on Saturday with passengers and London mails Passengers proceeding by the "Heliopolis" to Marseilles on the 26th inst. must leave Cairo by the 7.30 a.m. train at the latest on the same day.

div.head: Khartoum Season.
div.p: The first dance of the season took place on the 14 inst., in the new ballroom of the Grand Hotel Khartoum. Dinner was served in the open air, the gardens were beautifully decorated and illuminated, and visitors had a very pleasant evening

div.head: A Curious Find.
div.p: Some inconvenience has of late been caused to the residents in the new Ghezireh Government houses (known colloquially in Cairo as the ''Almshouses') owing to the stoppage of a drain. A native, who was among the workmen charged with the task of discovering the reason for the blocking of the drain, on cleaning it out discovered that a purse had penetrated into the orifice and had effectually stopped the passage of the drainage. As there is no name on the purse and it contains nothing inside sufficient to identify its original owner it is still awaiting a claimant

div.head: DEPARTURE OF MAHMAL.
div.p: The final ceremonies connected with the departure of the holy Kiswet were observed with all due pomp on Satorday morning, a vast number of spectators witnessing the imposing spectacle. The best view was obtained from the stand, erected on the further side of the parade ground and exactly opposite the Mastaba, to which access was reserved for those who travelled to the Citadel by the trains of the Egyptian Light Railway, From thence all the preliminaries and actual ceremonies were seen with full effect against the impressive background of the Citadel, with its high walls and rampants outlined by fringes of native onlodkers, and its domed mosque and slender minarets breaking the blue skyline beyond. Long regular Jines of stalwart soldiers bordered the parade ground, while one's eyes were constantly attracted to the Mastaba opposite which was constantly receiving fresh additions to its group of gorgeously attired officials, many of whose gold laced uniforms were crossed with resplendent orders. The entourage of H.H. the Khedive was seen approaching Lancers gay with fluttering pennons of green and scarlet dashed up the sanded roadway below the Citadel, followed by the high swinging carriage with its four horses and scarlet liveried attendants, wherein sat in state H.H. Abbas Helmi II escorted by his chief officials. Soldiers came to attention, spectators rose to their feet, as the massed band struck up the Khedivial march, and the salute rent the air, as Egypt's ruler left his carriage and took his place on the canopied seat in the Mastaba. Then the Mahmal, between two lines of police, and followed by native musicians mounted on their camels moved into position and slowly circled round and round, the glittering top heavy erection swaggering and courtseying at every movement of the slowly pacing camel. Finally it was led up to the steps of the Mastaba where it received the formal benediction of the Khedive before proceeding on its way, still followed by the musicians playing plaintive melodies on their uncouth instruments. More salutes followed its departure the shouts of the menand the shrill cries of the women being heard in the interludes. Then came the march past of the troops of the Egyptian Army, Lancers, Infantry, Mule Batteries and Artillery passing in quick succession to the inspiriting strains of the band, which followed down the road behind them. A few moments after and the Khedive took his place in the carriage and drove across the ground attended by his escort, followed by the Princes and high officials, the closed carriages of the ladies of high rank, the European notables and finally by the long line of heterogeneous vehicles which had been cooped up in the various enclosures

div.head:
EGYPTIAN CONSTRUCTIONS LIMITED
EXTRAORDINARY GENERAL MEETING
div.p: The extraordinary General Meeting of the Egyptian Constructions Limited, which was held at the Continental Hotel on Saturday afternoon, terminated to the complete satisfaction of the Directors, the proposed resolutions being carried without serious dissent. The Chairman in his introductory remarks pointed out that the position of the company demanded immediate attention in view of the present serious financial situation, the want of cash being acutely felt, and forcing the company to refuse much good work on account of lack of funds. The only thing required, in the opinion of the directors, to ensure the success of the company, was the raising of additional working capital, and it was with a view to obtaining, this that the following resolutions would be put to the meeting 1. That the capital of the company consist Ing of £200,000 divided into 200,000 shares of £1 each be reduced to £132,750 divided into 265,500 shares of 10 - each AS follows. (a) By cancelling 12,500 shares numbered 5001-7500 and 100001-110000 each fully paid. (b) By reducing each of the 109,500 shares numbered 1-5000, 7501-100000 and 110001- 122000 each fully paid from £1 to 10/. 2. That each of the 78,000 shares of £1 each remaining unissued shall be divided into two shares of 10 each. Should the above resolutions be duly passed by the requisite majority the same will be duly submitted for confirmation as special resolutions at a subsequent general meeting of the company which will be held at the same time and place on Wednesday the 8th day of January 1908, when a resolution authorizing the directors to sell or otherwise dispose of certain portions of the businesses acquired by the company will also as submitted. With regard to these proposed sales, we were unable to obtain a copy of the statement read to the meeting in time for press to-day, but this will appear in a future issue, but the main features of the proposals are that the company intends to resell to their former owners the businesses purchased respectively from Grant, Bondi and Chinn, Mark T. Boyes and the McClure branch of the business of McClure and Dorling The sale of the former to carry with it an opinion whereby the company would be enabled to repurchase the business within a period of 2 years, on the same terms as those of the original purchase, Mr. Bondi to remain managing director of the company It is proposed to resell the business purchased from Mark T. Boyes for the sum of £4,000, the Company to retain land subject to mortage of the on sale being £8,300. The McClure branch, for which the company paid £18,000, to be sold back to McClure and Dorling for 2,500 shares ; Mr. Dorling relinquishes all rights of directorship, and takes over stock, on the company lost considersably Bad and doubtful debts, estimated at 10 written off out-standing debta are approximately £7,045, the heaviest liability of the Company being the Bank overdraft of £20,000 At the conclusion of the statements of the Chairman, M. Wenger requested that some explanation should be given as to the loss on the San Stefano estate, the answer given being that a loss had occurred Sir Horace Pinching remarked that he should like to know the reasons of the general losses sustained. The company were now proposing to reduce their capital and dispose of a large portion of their business and if this continued, as far as he could see it seemed that at the end of 1908, the company would be in much the same position, and would probably wish to dispose of what was left. The Chairman in reply said that the reasons for the proposed reductionus Was that the company was badly in need of capital. The shares cannot be sold at the present rate, and the new issue would make the disposal of shares much easier. Sir Horace Pinching then touched upon the question of dividend of 7 which was declared, and which the shareholders had not yet received. The chairman replied that want of funds had prevented the payment of this dividend hitherto, but that it would be paid out of the sums which it was now proposed to raise. He admitted that the company had made a mistake in purchasing first and trusting to raising capital later, a course which the state of financial depression had prevented from realization, to which Sir Horace replied that the company had been started long before the adverse financial position had prevented the raising of any money which was required. After various other questions by M. Biddulph and others had been dealt with Mr. Montagu Summers rose and said that in his opinion the directors were to be thanked for the frank manner in which they had laid the position of the company before the shareholders, and speaking as a large shareholder himself he thought that the proposals which they had just heard were in every way the best that could be made for the benefit of the company. At the present moment the shares were practically unsaleable and if this state of things continued the company would have no other course left it but to go into liquidation, the lack of capital leaving the company almost entirely in the hands of the people from whom the businesses had been bought, but that if the proposed resolutions were carried be did not doubt but what the 10 - shares would very shortly rise to 15/- or even £1. Mr. Hill asked that if the resolutions were carried, what would be left to the company, and also asked how Mr. Bondi could remain in this company as director while competing with it in his own business. The Chairman replied that Mr. Bondi had been good enough to remain in the company and there would be no competition, and that there still remained the head office and the land at Rod el Parag. The Chairman then put the resolutions to the meeting and they were declared carried by a requisite majority on show of hands. Before the meeting broke up the chairman said that he wished it to be understood that the Company had nothing to hide and that any one who wished to investigate its position would be given every information at the offices of the company, and he gave instructions to the secretary to that effect. The following was the Balance Sheet of the Company as at 3lst March last. To Share Capital DR. L.E. M. 200.000 Ordinary Shares of £1 each 195.000 Insued 122.000 Ordinary Shares of £1 each 118.950. Less one-tenth written off Preliminary Expenses L.E. 1.321m.644 1.018.356 Special Reserve 750.000 Profitand Loss Account 8.726.219 L.E. 204.609.703 Cr. By Cash 4.214.078 Sundry Debtors 38.033.669 Deposits Lodged with the Egyptian Government and others against contracts Cash 2.924.689 Investments, Egyptian Unified 4 o/o Bonds at Cost 1.219.721 Land 8.328 Metres Rod-el Farag site of new workshope 15.136.799 Office Furniture and Fixtures 2.017.028 Less Depreciation L.E. 141.406m 1.855.622 Horses Carts 359.375 Less Depreciation LE. 13.500 345.875 Accounts paid in Advance 247.170 Buildings 1.950.O00 Stock on Hand, 31 March 1907 41.125.300 Work in Progress 42.782.134 Goodwill of business purchased to date 42.359.843 Preliminary Expenses 13.216.447 Less one-tenth written off General Reserve L.E. 1.321.644m 11.894.803 L.E. 204.609.703 In accordance with the provisions of the Companies' Act 1900, we certify that all our requirements as Auditors have been complied with. We have to report that the Stock was not taken on the 31st March 1909, except at the McClure and Dorling Branch, the Book figures of the stock being taken of all the other Branches and certified to by the Managers of those Branches. According to the Prospectus of the Company dated 17th February 1906 the total purchase price paid for certain specified assets of the Businesses acquired by the Company was £40,000 of which £30,000 was stated to represent the Goodwill. On examining the Accounts however we found that the Good. will included in the purchase price of £10,000 amounted to £33,446. Subject to the foregoing remarks we are of the opinion that the above Balance Sheet is drawn up so as to exhibit a true and correct view of the state of the Company's affairs as shown by the Books. RUSSELL, KERR AND WYATT, Chartered Accountants. Cairo, 30th May, 1907.

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE
div.p: On Saturday night the Italian Opera company engaged for the season by the Societa Artistica d'Egitto made its début at the Zizinia Theatre, Alexandria, in "Loreley," which will be played again tonight. The impression left upon the audience of this company was most favourable, and by Saturday night's performance we were led to hope for a season of quite good opera. There were certainly defects in the representation, but these may easily be remedied by practice. The most notable fault was a certain raggedness in the choral parts, and the orchestra seemed to us to be at times distinctively too heavy, though we had the misfortune to be almost sitting on the top of the big drum, so to speak. The ballet was clumsy, and the first dance was quite devoid of art — indeed it would have been far better to omit it altogether. Of the principals two shone, and they must have been greatly pleased with the uproarious applause of a most enthusiastic audience. Signora Crusceniski was really good as Loréley ; her voice is clear, pure, and true, and though she is not a great actress she carried out her part of Siren, well. Signor Rusconi too, was good as Rudolfo, but Signor Cristalli, as Walter was rather disappointing ; his voice being rather cold and sometimes even harsh, while his actions were unconvincing. As the fiancée and bride Signora Finzi did not seem quite up to the mark, but she has a powerful and well-trained voice, which she appeared to somewhat overstrain. After tonight's performance, however, of the same opera we shall be able to judge the company better, for on Saturday, first night awkardness was apparent, especially in the chorus. We would impress upon the management, however, the necessity for curtailing the intervals, which were most unduly prolonged and very, very tedious. To-morrow night we are to hear the ever popular "Faust," with Signor Narciso Del Ry as Mephistofele, from whom great things are expected as a singer of much promise.

On Friday the 13th the S.S. "El Kahira" took the blue ribbon of this run away from the S.S. "Prince Abbas," by arriving at 7.30 p.m. just under 50 hours steaming from Suez; many thanks came from the passengers to Mr. Wayman, the chief engineer, who worked hard the whole time. Among the passengers arriving was the British Consul of Jeddah who went down to Suakim in the vessel and joined the S.S. "Mahallah" for his return to Jeddah, also Mr. Little who left later for Khartoum. On the 14th inst., the S.S. "Nidderdale" arrived with a large quantity of cargo which will take some days to discharge. Port Sudan is not sorry, as amongst the many passengers there are some good fellows who are fond of sport. We must not forget to mention the Captain who is certainly No. 1 at all games. The Port Sudan Sports Club have got up many matches of both football and cricket for their benefit but I am pleased to say that they have not given us a beating yet, "Well done Port Suddenites." Quite a number of accidents have occurred here lately. One was most serious in which Mr. Cochilani of the firm of Messrs. Bencini and Quistas, the quay contractors, was the victim. It appears that they were blasting the coral reef and this gentleman was standing quite 80 yards away from the scene, when a sharp piece of coral fell on his head, cutting it open. He was carried to his house near by, and the doctors were called in; meanwhile everything was done to keep him conscious. It will be sometime before he is quite well again. Another exciting accident occurred in the shape of a runaway train on a siding where the railways are building the new line to meet the bridge. All the soldiers employed on the work endeavoured to stop it but to no effect, and the soldiers who were near the stop block received not only the contents but the trucks as well on top of them. It was surprising that so few were injured, one only being taken to the hospital. Great alarm has been caused amongst the natives by a motor car, which has just arrived in the "Nidderdale" for the Sirdar who will be shortly visiting the Port. This car is undoubtedly the best that ever put wheels on Port Sudan soil. The makers, Messrs. Arrol and Johnson, are to be congratulated upon turning out such a splendid car, which has been specially made with paddle wheels for gripping the sand. A trial run has been made on another car of the road to Khor-ah-Bat where they intend obtaining the water supply for this town, and which the Sirdar is going out to inspect.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL RECEPTIONS
div.p: On Saturday the Khedive received in private audience Prince Hussein Pasha, Sir Eldon Gorst, Mr. Barker, who presented Mr. H. Hooker, Norwegian Consul, and Mr. Whitworth Jones.

div.head: CASSA DI SCONTO
div.p: The pleadings of Maltres Guidotti, Mercinier and Manusardi in the case of Emin Azmy Bey v. the Liquidators of the Cassa di Sconto ended at 1 p.m. to-day. Maitre Lebsohn will reply for the Liquidators at the sitting of the Commercial Court on the 6th proxo. The Parquet has intervened in the case and asked for the documents and conclusion to be communicated to it. The conclusion of the Ministére Public will also be heard on the 6th proxo. The Court was crowded this morning.

div.head: RECRUDESCENCE OF CHOLERA.
div.p: This morning's telegrams report that out of 10 cases of cholera at Mecca 5 have proved fatal, while from Sinope the news is still more serious. There 72 cases from the Russian pilgrim steamer "Gregory Merek" were landed in quarantine the other day, and of this number 57 have died. The "Gregory Merek" was allowed to proceed to Port Said, where she is now in quarantine, and she will be sent through the canal under the strictest guard to prevent any possibility of communication with the shore. Cholera has also broken out aboard the Khedivial Mail S.S '"Dahabeah" among pilgrims taken from Yambo, and the sanitary authorities have ordered the "Dahabeah" to proceed to Camaran to undergo a quarantine period of ten days.

div.head: ALL SAINT'S CHURCH, RAMLEH.
div.p: Holy Communion 7:30 and 8:30 a.m. Mattins and Holy Communion with Sermon 11 a.m. Children's Service 3:30 p.m. Evensong 6:30 p.m.

div.head: PARIS-HOUSE GENEVA.
div.p: Mm. Auberge is exhibiting her models at the Hotel Villa Victoria, Cairo

div.head: PORT SAID STRIKE
div.p: The coal discharging Arabs have come out on strike in sympathy with the bunkering men who left work without notice on Thursday night. Last Tuesday was really the beginning, as that night a gang of bunkering Arabs on their way to the harbour were stopped by other Arabs who tried to persuade them to turn back. There was a sharp scuffle, but fortunately the police arrived promptly and one of the ringleaders was arrested. The masters of the gang who endeavoured to start the strike requested their sheikh to dismiss three other men who were ringleaders in the scuffle of Tuesday night. Things went on as usual till Thursday evening when a gang was called down to bunker the S.S. "Tydeus." When the gang arrived they were accompanied by the three men who had been dismissed, and then the trouble began. The three discharged men refused to leave the coal lighters and started making a disturbance with the result that the police were sent for and they were arrested. Immediately the men were arrested the whole gang returned to their village and refused to work. The coal agents for the S.S. "Tydeus" applied to the neighbours for assistance but all gangs refused to work till the arrested men had been released and allowed to rejoin their gang. The mounted and foot police from Cairo are encamped in the streets dividing the Arab village from the European quarter and no doubt the sight of so many police will have a good effect on the strikers.

div.head: SAVOY DANCE
div.p: Whatever pessimists may find to say regarding the present season, there need be no fear of a slump in the popularity of the Savoy dances, if that of last Saturday may be taken as a sample. It was the cheeriest evening we have seen this season, and was attended by seemingly the entire military contingent, and by the greater part of the residential and visiting population of the place. Varions improvements have been made in the hotel since last year, and the extra door from the ball room, and the increased sitting-out accomodation were highly appreciated by the guests. The new restaurant, too, is a great addition, and its delightful scheme of decoration is bound to add to its popularity; many people took this opportunity of dining and among them being a large party of old Rugbeans who were up holding the honour of their old school. There were as usual a number of handsome toilettes to be noticed in the ball room: the new comers proving themselves every whit as well dressed as those of the past and record season. Mrs. Darrell was a very noticeable figure in a beautiful and most original frock of deep purple chiffon moanted over scarlet satin. Mrs. Appleton, who, has already established a reptitation for always being beautifully gowned, was wearing on this occasion a filmy dress of dark blue with masses of blue sequins upon the decolletage. Miss Schulyer Ross, who is staying at the Savoy with Mrs. Ross, was much admired in a beautifully fitting white satin gown, with a deep lace berthe, and a black ornament in her exquisitely fair hair. Colonel and Mrs. Davidson who have only just arrived in Cairo were present with Miss Davidson, who looked charming in cream net trimmed with bands of satin. Mrs. Hornblower brought her niece Miss Smith also in white, and with Mrs. Royle's party was Miss Barnes Lawrence in a filmy white frock lightly diamantic and inset with heavy motifs of guipure d'Irelande. Princess Irene Duleep Singh, who was in deep rose colour with lace guimpe, was with Mrs. and Miss Carey, the latter looking very handsome in pale pink satin. The Misses Coles were in fresh and dainty pale blue frocks of empire make, the lappels of their bodies outlined by silken ball fringes. Their cousin was in a very handsome frock of white silk, inset with many entredeux and applications of lace. Miss Morss, who is staying with her mother at Shepheards, was quite one of the most popular belles present, and looked very well in a dress of fine muslin much tucked and inset with lace, and with a blue bow in her hair. Mrs. Carver made a very welcome return to the scene of her old triumphs, and looked very well in a pretty frock of soft striped blue material. Mrs. Knight's white chiffon frock guaged round the waist, was weighted by the classical keypattern in gold ; and Mrs. Duffus was wearing a charming gown of grey and white striped silk, over an underdress of soft white muslin and lace. The Misses Hyde Page were wearing handsome satin dresses, one in pink and one in cream, with diamentee lace about the corsages, and Mrs. Parsons was also in cream satin with a soft white feather in her hair. Mrs. de Cossen had a big yellow paradis in her hair which toned with her pretty sparkling drees. Mrs. Nolan was in an empire frock of deep rose coloured and striped material with velvet of the same shade Mrs. Sillards pretty fresh frock was of painted muslin relieved with green and set into a lace yoke at the waist. Mra. Fraser was in brocade of various shades of brown, brown chiflon dividing the panels and draping the bodice. We noticed many dresses in various shades of red and wine colour, one notable one being in velvet ; and among those who wore black with good effect were Mrs. Royle, Mrs, Maclean, Mrs. Schreiber and Mrs, Bailey.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The Duchess of Aosta and suite have arrived at the Grand Hotel, Khartoum. The Duchess intends to take a trip up the White Nile to Gondokoro.

The KEarl and Countess of Sefton, Lord Eustace Cecil and Mr. A. Cecil, Major the Hon, Haugh Fraser, Mr. Sidney Low, the well-known London journalist, Mr. Douglas Sladen, the author, and his wife, and Kaimakam Mac Ewea Bey, of Wad Medani, have also been staying at the ground Hotel, Khartoum.

Other arrivals at this Khartoum hotel include: Mr. W.M. Aders, Mr. Russel A. Colvin, Mr. and Mrs. H.P. Hewins, Mr. O. Graham, Mr. H.S. Job, Mr. and Mrs. Harcourt Paine, Mr. M. Chrestie, Mr. M. Graham, Mr. Russel Rea, Mr. A. Nislen, Mr. B.K. Miller, Mr. and Mrs. Percy C. Moreton, Miss Norma Lorimer, Miss Potter, Mr. H.A. Little, Mr. Graham Morrison.
Prince and Princess Windischgraetz, who are staying at the Cataract Hotel, Assouan, are on their way to the Sudan, where the Prince intends going on a big-game shooting expedition.

Prince Mirza Riza Khan, the Persian Ambassador at Constantinople, arrived this morning at Alexandria by the Khedivial S.S. "Ismailia," His Highness is accompanied by Ohannes Khan, first dragoman of the Embassy. His absence from the Ottoman Capital will be about three weeks' duration.

Yesterday's arrivals at Alexandria by the Florio-Rubattino's S.S. "Regina Margherita" included the Countess Adamoli and her daughters, the Countess Voltre Bronte Mr Leopold Jullien, Manager of the Union Fonciere, and Mrs. Jullien, Major General Cerri, Major General di Lorenzo, Lieut. General Sapelli, Commander Bianchi, Captain Racina, etc.
Among the arrivals at Alexandria to-day by the Austrian Lloyd's S.S. "Semiramis," were Mr. Salvago, Mr. Zervudachi, Mr. Sachs, Mr. E. Aghion, etc.

Mr. Douglas Sladen is busy garnering materials and local colour for his new book. Mr. Sladen is staying at Khartoum with a party of four. Mr. Sladen is the chief critic of "the Queen." He is a great traveller and the author of several books. We understand that he is going to travel in this country and to write a book on the Sudan, which will no doubt be well received in the literary world. On Saturday week he called at the Palace and was cordially received the Sirdar.

Mr. A. Salone, Chief Greffier of the Mixed Courts at Alexandria, has been appointed Inspector General of the Mixed Courts. His successor will be Mr. De Bono, Conservator of Mortgage Deeds at the Mixed Courts.

div.head: DEATH OF A MOSS LINE SUPERINTENDENT.
div.p: The death occurred recently, at his residence, 33, Great George-road, Waterloo, of Captain William Owen, marine superintendent of the Moss Line of steamers. Deceased, who was sixty-seven years of age, was highly esteemed in shipping circles. He joined the Moss Line Company in 1866 as junior officer, and rapidly rose to a captaincy. In turn he commanded nearly all the steamers of the line. In 1891 he was appointed marine superintendent of the line, a position he held with credit and distiction up to the time of his demise. His death was not expected, as he was at business a few days before his death. Messrs. R.J. Moss and Co, inform us that he was buried on Saturday, 14th, inst., at Anfield. The House Flags were hoisted half-mast by the Moss, Ellerman and Papayanni Liners in port from the 11th to the 14th in token of respect for the deceased, who was well known here. By his death the Moss S.S. Co., Ltd., lose one of their most trusted and valuable friends and officials.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE.
div.p: La séance de ce matin a été une réédition des précédentes, 4 cette différence prée que les affaires se sont encore raréfides, si possible, et que la corbeille a été videou a peu prés pen- dant la plus grande partie de la matinée. Les offres ont oocasionné une nouvelle dépréciation dela cote. Celan'a d'ailleurs rien d'étonnant avec une situation générale aussi peu encoo- rageante, |'élévation du taux privé d'escompte de 5 7/8 a 6% et l'approche des fétes de Noél et du Nouvel An. A cette occasion le marché des valeurs sera fermé les mercredi et jeudi 25 et 26 courant, ainsi que ler et 2 janvier prochain.

Il y a eu ce matin une exécution comprenant 100 Delta Land, 100 Egyptian Land Invest. ment and Building(Fanous) et 100 Ritz Hotels. Ces titres ont trouvé preneurs aux cours res pectifs de 1 3/32, 9/64 et 1/4-17/64.

Parmi lea valeurs dirigeantes l'Agricole fléchit de 7 25/82 47 8/4, la National Bank de 20 A '9 18/16, et la Delta Light de 93/4 a 9 1Y16. On continue a vendre les obligations anciennes Crédit Foncier qui tombent pour ce motif de 279 1/2 & 276 1/2; c'est le plus bas prix constaté non seulement ao coors de la crise actuelle mais depuis plusieurs années. La seule explication plausible qu'on donne de ce fait anormal c'est que la plupart des autres titres sont en ce moment difficiles pour ne pas dire impossibles 4 négocier. Seule de cette ca- tégorie la Daira Sanieh reprend légérement de 12 1/F a 12 9/16.

En baisse également la Ramieh de 4 3/85 & 4 5/16, les Dividendes Tramways d' Alexandre de 278 & 277, la Béhéra de 20 8 8 A 20 1/4, les Nungovich Hotels de 147 8 & 1486/4, le Crédit Franco Egyptien de 4 1/32 a 4. Les Lots Tures remontent, au contraire, de 160 4 161 et la Banqaoe d'Orient de 111 a 111 1/4.

Nous constatons le méme mouvement de recul parmi les titres d'ordre secondaire. A part la Port Said Salt qui se reléve un peu de 11/9 & 11/10 1/2, toutes les autres varia. tions indiquent un nouveau fiéchissement.

C'est ainsi que de 13/- la Salt and Soda ré encore a 12 9, l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail de 11/32 & 5/16, les Estates de 3/8 A 11/82, la Building Lands de 1 1/2 a 1 7/16, 'United de 7/32 a 3/16, |'Egyptian Land Investment and Building de 1/4 41/8 et la Levico de 5/16 & 9/32.
Pour le momen: la tendance est mauvaise et les circonstances ne font gutre prévoir de reprise, si reprise il y a, avant les premiers mois de l'année prochaine.

div.head: Egyptian State Railways
div.p: NOTICE.
SALE OF COTTON AND Cotton SEED BY PUBLIC AUCTION AT GABBARY STATION

The Administration has the honour to inform the Public that on Monday, 30th December, 1907, and following days, if necessary, at 3.p.m., there will be put up to auction at Gabbary Station (Inward Stores), under the following conditions, about 65 TONS OP COTTON AND 268 TONS OF COTTON SEED:
1. No one will be admitted to the auction unless he pays in advance the sum of FIFTY EGYPTIAN POUNDS (in Cash, Egyptian Bonds or other values accepted by the Administration) as a deposit.

This deposit will bear no interest but is to serve as a guarantee for the Administration and to ensure the execution of the following clauses, and can, if necessary, be deducted from the price of an article purchased at the auction.
The deposit should be personal and in the name of the depositor acting on his own account.
2. Bidders should examine the condition, quantity and quality of the goods put up for auction before remitting the deposit.

3. The fact of competing at the auction involves acceptance on the part of the bidder of the condition, quality, etc., of the goods, and co claim relating thereto will be accepted. 4. Once the tender is accepted, the bidder must -
(a) Pay in at once and in full the price, deduction being made of his deposit;

(b) Withdraw, after payment, at his own expense and risk, the goods purchased as soon as the price has been paid in (packing being in his charge) but, in any case, the goods will be at his own risk from the moment the tender is accepted.

5. In case of refusal on the part of the bidder to pay the full price, or to withdraw the articles purchased, within 24 hours at the latest, the Administration will have the right to put up the goods to auction again at the bidder's risk. In case, huwever, a higher price is offered, the first offer will be definitely forfeited.
6. The Administration reserves the right -
(a) Of selling the goods in one or more lots;
(b) Of renouncing the sale after the opening of the auction but before the tender is accepted;
(c) Of treating amicably for part or all the goods;
(d) Of adjudging the sale to a person other than the last and highest bidder
In any case, the bidder will have the right to the refund of his deposit, but without in. terest or any indemnity whatever.

div.head:
THE PALERMO DISASTER
FUNERAL OF VICTIMS

div.p: The funeral of the identified victims took place here this afternoon in the presence of Cardinal Lualdi, Deputies, Senators, and 5000 mourners. The scene was most impressive. The Mayor made an oration. Many were moved to tears. The town was draped in black. (Reuter)

Mr. Taft, in the course of an interview here, said that it was nonsense to think that the Japanese were anti-American. They were not concerned about the Pacific cruise, which they consider as a mere naval test. (Reuter)
Tbe Army Council h*s adopted the Japanese bayonet which is three inches longer than the British one and proved terribly effective in Mancbnria. (Reuter)
The "Standard" learns that the Admiralty has decided to establish a Pacific North American squadron next May. consisting of the fourth cruiaer squadron and six cruisers of the "County" class (Reuter)
The Admiralty most emphatically contradicts the "Standard" statement. ( Reuter)
The Cotton Employers' Federation has fixed the date of the lock out as 18th January- 150,000 workers will be affected. (Reuter)
The columns of General Lyautey have entered the mountains, occuping villages and destroying two of them. The rapidity of their advance is overawing the tribes (Reuter)

The two French columns operating on the Algero-Moroccan frontier have entered the mountain ranges and occupied villages. The recalcitrant tribes and emissaries are coming in and paying the fines exacted by the French. (Reuter)

A considerable sensation has been caused owing to the De Beers Mine not paying a dividend on the deferred shares owing to a large diminution in the demand for diamonds, mainly due to American crisis. (Reuter)

The Emperor for the first time since his illness drove from Schoenbrunn to Hofburg and received the delegations. In a speech he emphasized the continued satisfactory international situation, and said that the increased demands of the War Department were confined to what was absolutely necessary (Reuter)

Official statistics show that 22,840 persons perished owing to mining accidents in America within the past 17 years, half of which number lost their lives during the past 6 years, and 2,061 during 1906 (Reuter)
There are 10 cases of cholera at Mecca, 5 of which have proved fatal. (Reuter)

At the reception of the Austrian delegation, the Poles and Czechs, protested against the Prussian anti Polish legislation. Baron Aehrenthal insisted on the non interference with the internal affairs of foreign states. (Reuter)

Reichsrath The Minister of Finance, referring to the satisfactory state of the finances, said that tbe Government did not require to issue 500,000,000 kronen of stock which it was empowered to do (Reuter)
The Chamber of Deputies has adopted a bill dealing with the appropriation of Ecclesiastical property and completing the separation law (Reuter)

The Russian legation has replied to the Persian manifesto to the effect that Russia will abstain from interference in Persian internal affairs, and will confine herself to the protection of the frontiers and of her subjects. (Reuter)

The Shah has received in audience the British and Russian representatives and solemnly assured them that he did not intend to abolish the constitutional regime, but would strive to work with it. (Reuter)
The Second Chamber has rejected the Army estimates framed by the new War Minister who does not command the confidence of the Chamber (Reuter)
2,600 workmen of the Lloyd Arsenal have gone on strike. (Reuter)
The Chamber of Deputies has passed a bill making the circulation of notes more elastic. The Chamber has adjourned till 4th February. (Reuter)
M.C.C 321 runs for 7 wickets (Reuter)
Ullmo has been re-imprisoned (Havas)

The Oulad el Hady entered Fez on the 16th and 17th inst. and caused fights. The octroi and merchant quarters were pillaged. The French post office was attacked, but the rioters respected the German post. The authorities are powerless and asked for troops from Rabat (Havas)
Disorders caused by the strikers of saltpetre works caused the intervention of the troops. Seven persons were killed. (Havas)

The "Journal" states that the affairs of the Ethiopian railway will be wound up in a few days in accordance with the arrangement between M.M. Pichon, Millies, and, Lacroix. A new French Company will he formed shortly (Reuter)

Parliament hat finally passed the Ausgleich. The Premier announced that an exchange of notes with the Austrian Premier regarding the resolution mentioned on the 18th instant had resulted in satisfactory guarantees being given. (Reuter)

A sensation has been caused here owing to the Engineer, Signor Arvedi, belonging to Verona, having been murdered in the train between Rome and Ancona. He was stabbed in the heart, breast, and eye. It is stated that he carried securities amounting to a considerable sum.
Sir Patrick Heron Watson (Reuter)

div.head: GOVERNMENT ACCOUNTS.
div.p: Mr. H.J. Gibson, Deputy Auditor-General in London, arrived here last month, together with Mr. Bunbury of the Auditor General's Department, for the purpose of examining into the system of accountancy and audit in the Island. Mr. Gibson is making an extended tour including British possessions in the Mediterranean and in West Africa, and is carrying out a very ample programme of work. He landed at Limassol and with Mr. Banbury proceeded to Nicosia by mole across the lower heights of the Southern mountain range. He was thus enabled to gain an idea of the country parts of the Island They remained only one week in Cyprus.

div.head: The Rainy Season.
div.p: Reports from all districts show that the rainstorms of a fortnight ago were very general. [n many localities the land was under water and damage was done. The Railway line to Morphou suffered from wash-outs, the effect, in one part, being very serious, a large portion of the embankment having been washed away leaving the rails and sleepers unsupported. No accidents to trains oncurred however.

A railway motor-car has lately been imported for the use of certain railway officials It is intended that it shall travel at a much greater speed than the ordinary train, and will frequently be used in the place of a special train. It shonld prove of considerable utility as well as economy in this respect.

div.head: Government Farm.
div.p: The Government farm at Athalassa, which has lately come under the direction of the Committee for the improvement of native animals, has lately received the following live stock from England : 1 Galloway bull, 2 Devon bulls, 4 large black pigs, and some head of poultry

div.head: Cypriot Poultry.
div.p: There is much room for improvement in the native breeds of poultry and Cyprus is an ideal place for poultry farming. Cyprus eggs compare favourably with the small eggs of inferior quality usually to be seen in Egypt, but new strains of fowls are much needed both for egg production and table purposes. If the use of incubators and foster mothers were to become general, an important and remunerative poultry trade might be done. The price of eggs is at present very high, half a piastre each in the towns, almost the same as in Egypt. Indeed as Egypt comes to be more and more more the market forall kinds of Cyprus produce, the cost price in this Island for such articles will necessarily approximate and be largely influenced by the prices obtainable in Egypt. It may be hoped that when better metbods of rearing poultry prevail here, a more humane system of hawking birds for sale will be adopted. The present custom of tying them by the legs and carrying them about by hand all day is very cruel, particularly in the case of beavy birds. Efforts have been made to introduce baskets and crates, but the existing practise still obtains generally, and will, doubtless, die hard.

div.head: Rough Seas.
div.p: The heavy seas which have lately prevailed around our coasts have made the process of shipments and unloading of goods and the embarkation and disembarkation of passengers very difficult in the roadsteads of Limassol and Larnaca. The charge of £1 per person, which has had to be paid at both the ports for getting from vessel to land is a considerable addition to the travelling expenses, and isa great increase upon the ordinary charge of 2s The entrance to the port of Famagusta, too, is very difficult of access in rough weather, and and veseels baveto take a long sweep up the coast before turning and making for the harbour.

div.head: Personalia.
div.p: The Venerable Beresford Potter, Archdeacon in Cyprus, and Mra. Potter have arrived in Cyprus this week fora stay of some duration
Among Officials returned from leave last week were Mr. A.K. Bovill, Principal Forest Officer, Mra, Bovill and children, and Mr. Michell, Commissioner of Limassol, Mrs. and the Misses Michell.

Mr. H.A. Smallwood, iate Island Treasurer in Oypros, was taken ill on board ship on his way to England in October, and was suffering from fever for some time after his arrival. He has now recovered sufficiently to sail with his wife and children for St. Lucia.

The death was lately announced of Mr. Ridings in Northern Nigeria. Mr. Ridings was in Cyprus some two years engaged in the construction of the Government Railway. He became very popular among the English community and his early death is mach regretted by his many friends here. Great sympathy is felt for Mrs. Ridings who resided for some time in the Island in order to be near her son.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY
div.p: Vice Admiral the Honourable Bir Hedworth Lambton, K. C. V. O., late commanding the Third Cruiser Squadron, attached to the Mediterranean Fleet, has been selected to succeed Admiral Sir A W. Moore, K. C. B., in command of the China Squadron and Eastern Fleet next Mare.

Captain A. F. C. Maclachlan, 3rd Battalion King's Royal Rifle Corps, Aldershot (under orders for Crete) has been appointed adjutant of the Battalion in succession to Captain the Hon. A. P. W. Harris, who has returned to regimental duty.
Lieutenant and Riding Master G. H. Beale, Provisional Cavalry Depot, Ballincollig, has been ordered to embark tor Cairo on the 18th inst.
The 2nd Battalion Queen's Own Cameron Highlanders has just left Durban for Tientsin, North China, it having teen decided to stiffen our forces there.

The split in the Navy League has resulted in the formation of a new organisation to carry out the propaganda work of those members who disapproved of the recent policy of the organisation, which in their opinion bad be. come paralysed by the desertion and reversal of the objects it was created to fulfil. The "Im perial Maritime League" has therefore been formed and it will concern itself not merely with the Royal Navy but also with merchant service. The objects. broadly speaking, of the new society are increase in the sea power of the British peoples, their closer union, and their intra-Imperial organisation for defence. Its specific aims will be the command of the sea as a national policy, since this is the sole eondition of onr national life. The new organisation will also advocate the creation of a Strategy Department and the maintainence of a high standard of naval strength equal to a clear 10 per cent. superiority over the next two strongest navies in the world, with the proviso that the standard may be raised in the event of the international relationships of the British Empire being changed to its disadvantages. Another obeject will be the adoption of legislation with the view of securing the elimination as far as possible of the foreign element in the British mercantile marine, and the improvement of the position and prospects of the mercantile officer and men, without detriment to the British sbipowner, and advocacy of all means which shall tend to unite and simpilty the action of Great Britain and of the younger nations throughout the empire in all matters of detence, sea borne trade, and commerce.

div.head: Soolote Anonymo dos Eaux du Caire
div.p: AVIS

Les porteurs des certificats provisoires aux nouvelles actions de Jouissance émises en Juin 1907 sont informés que le solde de la gouscription, soit Prs. 90- Ou P.T. 347,175 par action est payable le ler Janvier 1908.

Les versements devront être effectués au Caire, au siège de la Société, Avenue de Boulaq ouk Alexandrie au Guicbet du Credit Lyonnais où, en méme temps, les certificats provisoires seront échanges contre les titres définitifs.

En cas de retard dans les versements, il y aura lieu de plein droit à l'application de l'ar ticle II des statuts ainsi conçu : Art. II. - A défaut de versement aux époques déterminées, l'intérêt court de plein droit à la charge de l'actionnaire, à raison de six pour cent par an, pour chaque jour de retard. Le retardataire est mis en demeure d'effectuer ses paiements par un avis insére dans un des journaux désignés à l'article 8; cet avis indique les numéros des actions en retard. Paote par l'actionnaire de se libérer dans le délai d'un mois, et sans qu'il soit nécessaire de recourir à aucune formalité de justice, ni d'ajouter à ce laps d'un mois aucun délai en raison des distances, les actions en retard seront vendues publiquement sur duplicata, dans la forme qu'indiquera le Conseil d'Administration, le tout sans préjudice du droit que la Société conserve de poursuivre personnellement l'actionnaire en retard Les titres priinitifs des actions ainsi vendues sont nuls de plein droit. En conséquence toute action qui ne porte pas la mention régulière des versements qui ont dû être opérés, cesse d'être admissible à la négociation et au transfert.
Le Directeur,
ASTLEY P. FRIEND Le Caire, le 5 Décembre 1907.

div.head: SUDAN MEDICAL DEPARTMENT, SUDAN.
div.p: The Sudan Medical Department is in need of the services of a qualified dispenser with pay com inencing £16 per mensem. Applications for this post will be addressed to the Director Sudan Medical Department, Khartoum. They should be accompanied with all certificates, testimonials, references, etc., and with a duly filled up Application torm which is obtainable (together with any intormation as to pay, increase of pay, conditions of service, etc.,) from the Sudan Agency, War Office, Cairo. A good knowledge of English and Arabic (reading and writing) is indispensable. The chosen candidate will be taken on probation for a period of two years.

div.head: Municipalite d'Alexandrie
div.p: AVIS

La Municipalité met en adjudication la fourniture des Gargouilles et Sabots nécessaires A son service. Le cautionnement est fixé « L. E. 30 (trente.) Le cahier des charges est déposé au bureau Technique où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h à midi, les jours fériés exceptés. Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 7 Janvier 1908. Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour à 5 h. p.m. L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la men. tion : " Soumission pour fourniture Gargouilles et Sabots." Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 7 Janvier 1908 à midi. Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
Alexandrie, le 20 Décembre 1907.
L'Administrateur (Signe) W.P: CHATAWAY.
AVIS

La Municipalité met en adjudication la fourniture des articles nécessaires aux ronleaux compresseurs pendaut l'année 1908. Le cautiounement est fixé à L. Eg. 25 (vingt cinq.) Le cahier des charges est déposé au bureau Techuique où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h à midi, les jours fériés exceptés. Les offres devront être adressées sons pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 31 Décembre 1907. Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour à 5h. p.m. L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention "Soumission po or Fourniture Articles pour roulouux compresseurs." Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque d'après les conditions du cahier des charges devra être remis séparémeut au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 31 décembre a midi. Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera cartée.
Alexandrie, le 9 Décembre 1907.
L'Administrateur P. CHATAWAY.
